Award.AwardTitle: CC*IIE Engineer: Campus CI Engineer in Support of Data-Intensive Science and Knowledge-Sharing Statewide

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: This project evolves and sustains human expertise in advanced networking technologies to support data-driven science applications at the University of Alabama in Huntsville, and fosters a community of engagement, learning, and knowledge-sharing for cyberinfrastructure and cybersecurity professionals throughout Alabama and adjoining states. The campus CI Engineer plans and maintains the Science DMZ at UAH, identifying and addressing key campus network engineering and performance challenges, and building both a theoretical and practical knowledge base to contribute to the regional CI community, for which the CI Engineer acts as a resource. UAH is hosting a workshop for local, state, and regional professionals to address the challenges and opportunities inherent in advanced networking technologies to support data-driven science applications. Specific workshop sessions cover emerging topics in data networking and security such as Software Defined Networking (SDN), federated network measurements including perfSONAR, network tuning, federated identity management (InCommon), and security and policy development. A regional digital knowledge warehouse hosted at UAH complements the workshop in supporting the regional community of practice. This project augments and bridges outstanding activities and communities of practice elsewhere in the nation. The activities enable data-driven science of regional, national and international significance, and significantly augment the regional knowledge base of advanced networking expertise for the University of Alabama System Regional Optical Network (UASRON) and Alabama Research and Education Network (AREN), as well as for the entire University of Alabama system, with whom UAH collaborates via both a statewide CIO council, and a statewide Cybersecurity Council.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of Alabama in Huntsville (UAH) received a NSF grant to hire a Cyberinfrastructure (CI) engineer. Upon arrival at UAH, the CI engineer began to interact with the various science and research organizations on campus. After developing a dialog with these groups, the CI engineer worked with the Office of Information Technology to develop a long term roadmap for the enhancement of the network infrastructure. This included implementing higher bandwidth solutions to researchers and scientist as well as increasing available bandwidth off campus. Additionally the placement of perfSONAR performance monitoring solutions was approved and implemented, enabling the collection of performance data to/from critical points both on campus and off. Further enhancement of the overall network infrastructure occurred as the CI engineer worked further with OIT to develop and win an infrastructure improvement grant which furthered the capabilities of data communications on campus. 

Additionally, the CI engineer participated in several local and regional working groups to further advance network communications locally within the city as well as regionally throughout the southeast. The UAH CI engineer was a contributing member to the development of requirements and enhancements to the University of Alabama System Regional Optical Network (UASRON), improving data communicatations 100 fold. That endeavor was funded by the UA System (the UASRON upgrade). 

UAH utilized the funding to better understand the total requirements of science and research on campus while improving both current and future communication capabilities. The knowledge gained as part of this grant has been shared via local and national conferences as well as weekly teleconferences.
